tasks.description: Write a short informational article on a well-known topic
tasks.input: Write a 400-500 word article explaining why regular code reviews improve software quality. Target audience: junior developers. Use an accessible, encouraging tone.

scoring.5: Clear thesis within the first two paragraphs stating that code reviews improve quality, with a specific angle (e.g., catches bugs early, promotes knowledge sharing)
scoring.3: General statement about code reviews being useful but lacking a specific, arguable claim
scoring.1: No identifiable thesis; reads as a list of facts

scoring.5: At least two concrete supporting points with evidence (statistics, examples, or expert references); each point analyzed, not just stated
scoring.3: Supporting points present but evidence is generic or unsupported assertions
scoring.1: Claims without any evidence

scoring.5: Consistently accessible and encouraging tone appropriate for junior developers; no jargon without explanation; active voice; smooth flow
scoring.3: Mostly appropriate tone with occasional shifts to overly formal or condescending register
scoring.1: Tone mismatch â€” too technical or too patronizing for the audience

tasks.description: Write a practical how-to blog post with clear structure
tasks.input: Write a 400-500 word blog post titled 'How to Write a Great Git Commit Message'. Use a listicle or modular structure with clear sections. Target audience: developers of all levels.

scoring.5: Clear modular/listicle structure with introduction, 3+ distinct sections with subheadings, and a summary/conclusion; each section is self-contained
scoring.3: Some structure visible but sections blend together or lack clear headings
scoring.1: Wall of text with no structural organization

scoring.5: Practical, actionable advice with concrete examples of good and bad commit messages; explains the 'why' behind each practice
scoring.3: Advice is reasonable but generic; lacks concrete examples
scoring.1: Vague or incorrect guidance

scoring.5: Covers key aspects: subject line format, body content, imperative mood, scope, and provides a conclusion tying it together; appropriate length
scoring.3: Covers 2-3 aspects but misses important ones
scoring.1: Covers only one aspect superficially

tasks.description: Write a brief opinion piece with a clear position
tasks.input: Write a 300-400 word opinion piece arguing that open-source software is essential for innovation in the tech industry. Use a professional tone suitable for a tech publication.

scoring.5: Strong, specific thesis stated early; clear position that open-source is essential (not just 'useful') with a defined scope (innovation in tech)
scoring.3: Position is present but hedged or vague; reads more as 'open source is nice' than 'essential'
scoring.1: No clear position; balanced overview instead of an opinion

scoring.5: At least two distinct arguments with supporting evidence; logical progression from claim to evidence to analysis; brief acknowledgment of counterpoint
scoring.3: Arguments present but evidence is thin; no counterargument engagement
scoring.1: Assertions without supporting logic or evidence

scoring.5: Conclusion reinforces thesis, synthesizes arguments into a broader insight, and ends with a call to action or forward-looking statement
scoring.3: Conclusion restates the thesis but doesn't add new insight
scoring.1: Abrupt ending or vague summary

tasks.description: Write an analytical article requiring evidence integration and counterargument handling
tasks.input: Write a 700-900 word article analyzing whether remote work increases or decreases productivity for software engineering teams. Present evidence for both sides, take a clear position, and address the strongest counterargument. Target audience: engineering managers. Professional, data-informed tone.

scoring.5: Clear, nuanced thesis within first two paragraphs; takes a specific position (not 'it depends') with qualifiers (e.g., 'for senior engineers on established teams'); conclusion is consistent
scoring.3: Position is present but too hedged or appears late in the article
scoring.1: No clear position; article remains neutral throughout

scoring.5: Uses 3+ evidence types (statistics, case studies, expert quotes); evidence is properly attributed with source, date, and context; PEEL structure visible in body paragraphs
scoring.3: Some evidence present but not well-attributed; relies on one evidence type
scoring.1: Minimal evidence; mostly personal opinion or unverified claims

scoring.5: Strongest counterargument presented fairly using Rogerian approach; rebutted with specific evidence; concedes valid points while maintaining thesis
scoring.3: Counterargument acknowledged but dismissed superficially or presented as a straw man
scoring.1: Counterargument mentioned in passing without engagement

scoring.5: Analytical framework structure; consistent professional tone for engineering managers; smooth transitions; clear subheadings; varied sentence rhythm
scoring.3: Adequate structure but some tonal shifts or weak transitions
scoring.1: Poor structure; inconsistent tone; choppy flow

tasks.description: Write a narrative-driven feature article using storytelling techniques
tasks.input: Write a 700-900 word feature article about how a fictional startup pivoted from a failing product to a successful one by embracing user feedback. Use a narrative arc structure with a compelling opening scene, rising tension, and resolution. Target audience: entrepreneurs and product managers.

scoring.5: Clear narrative arc: engaging opening scene/hook, rising action with increasing tension, central problem/pivot moment, resolution with specific outcomes, reflection with broader lessons
scoring.3: Some narrative elements but flat tension curve; events listed chronologically without dramatic structure
scoring.1: No narrative structure; reads as an expository article about pivots

scoring.5: Business insights and evidence woven naturally into the narrative; specific details (metrics, user feedback quotes, product decisions) make the story credible and instructive
scoring.3: Some data points included but feel forced or disconnected from the narrative
scoring.1: Pure fiction with no instructive business evidence or lessons

scoring.5: Vivid characters (founder, team members, users) with distinct voices; concrete scenes with sensory details; the reader can visualize key moments
scoring.3: Characters are named but one-dimensional; scenes are described but lack vividness
scoring.1: No character development; abstract descriptions

scoring.5: Article concludes with actionable insights for the target audience; lessons are drawn from the narrative rather than appended; readers can apply the insights to their own work
scoring.3: Lessons stated but feel disconnected from the story; generic startup advice
scoring.1: No clear takeaway for the audience

tasks.description: Write an article requiring style adaptation to a specific audience
tasks.input: Write a 600-800 word article explaining Kubernetes container orchestration for a non-technical business audience. The article should justify why a company's leadership should invest in Kubernetes, using business language (ROI, scalability, operational efficiency) rather than technical jargon. Analogies are encouraged.

scoring.5: Entirely business-oriented language; no unexplained technical jargon; concepts framed in terms of business value (cost savings, reliability, speed to market); effective analogies that make technical concepts intuitive
scoring.3: Mostly business language but some technical terms leak through without explanation; analogies attempted but not fully effective
scoring.1: Heavy technical language; reads as a developer article with a few business terms added
scoring.0: No audience adaptation; pure technical article

scoring.5: Clear business case with specific benefits (cost reduction %, uptime improvement, deployment speed); addresses likely executive concerns (cost, complexity, timeline); evidence supports each benefit
scoring.3: Business benefits mentioned but vague ('it saves money'); doesn't address concerns
scoring.1: No clear business case; describes what Kubernetes does but not why it matters

scoring.5: Uses 2+ effective analogies that accurately represent the concept while being accessible (e.g., 'Kubernetes is like a shipping logistics manager...'); acknowledges where analogies simplify
scoring.3: One analogy present but not fully developed; or analogy is inaccurate
scoring.1: No analogies; abstract explanations only

scoring.5: Complete article with clear introduction, 3+ benefit sections, and conclusion with recommendation; appropriate length; well-organized for scanability
scoring.3: Covers some benefits but incomplete; structure needs work
scoring.1: Fragmentary or significantly too short/long

tasks.description: Write an article integrating multiple evidence types with proper attribution
tasks.input: Write a 600-800 word article about the impact of AI on software testing, arguing that AI-assisted testing will complement rather than replace human testers. Include at least one statistic, one expert perspective, one case study or example, and one logical argument. Target: QA professionals. Professional, informed tone.

scoring.5: Includes all 4 requested evidence types (statistic, expert perspective, case study, logical argument); each is properly attributed with source, context, and date; evidence types are distributed across different argument blocks
scoring.3: Includes 2-3 evidence types; attribution is incomplete
scoring.1: Only one evidence type used; poor attribution

scoring.5: Every piece of evidence is followed by analysis explaining what it means and how it supports the argument (PEEL structure); evidence is woven into the narrative, not dropped in
scoring.3: Some evidence is analyzed but others are stated without interpretation
scoring.1: Evidence is listed without analysis

scoring.5: Clear 'complement not replace' thesis stated early; arguments logically build the case with specific examples of complementary roles
scoring.3: Thesis present but arguments are generic
scoring.1: Vague position; doesn't clearly argue complement vs. replace

scoring.5: Professional, informed tone respecting QA professionals' expertise; uses QA-specific terminology appropriately; addresses their real concerns (job security, skill evolution)
scoring.3: Generally appropriate but occasionally condescending or too basic for QA professionals
scoring.1: Tone mismatch; either too academic or too casual for the audience

tasks.description: Write a long-form article on a contentious topic requiring balanced evidence, strong counterargument handling, and sophisticated structure
tasks.input: Write a 1000-1200 word article for a technology policy publication arguing whether governments should mandate algorithmic transparency for AI systems used in hiring decisions. Take a clear position, present evidence from multiple domains (technology, law, ethics, business), engage with the two strongest counterarguments, and propose a specific policy recommendation. Formal, authoritative tone.

scoring.5: Specific, nuanced thesis stated within first two paragraphs; clear policy recommendation (not just 'transparency is good'); scoped to hiring AI specifically; conclusion reinforces with implementation specifics
scoring.3: Position present but vague or overly general; recommendation lacks specificity
scoring.1: Balanced overview without taking a position; no policy recommendation

scoring.5: Evidence drawn from all 4 requested domains (technology, law, ethics, business) with proper attribution; domains are connected, not siloed; at least 5 distinct evidence items across the article
scoring.3: Evidence from 2-3 domains; some well-attributed, others generic
scoring.1: Evidence from only one domain or unattributed claims

scoring.5: Two strongest counterarguments identified and presented fairly (Rogerian approach); each rebutted with specific evidence; valid points conceded; overall argument strengthened by the engagement
scoring.3: One counterargument addressed adequately; second missing or treated as straw man
scoring.1: Counterarguments mentioned but not seriously engaged

scoring.5: Analytical framework structure with clear progression; transitions create a logical chain between sections; subheadings guide the reader; introduction and conclusion frame the article as a coherent argument
scoring.3: Adequate structure but some sections feel disconnected; transitions need work
scoring.1: Poor organization; arguments presented randomly

scoring.5: Consistently formal, authoritative tone appropriate for a policy publication; precise language; no casual expressions; demonstrates deep domain familiarity through vocabulary and framing
scoring.3: Mostly formal but occasional informalities; vocabulary sometimes imprecise
scoring.1: Tone inconsistencies; shifts between formal and casual; vocabulary too basic for a policy audience

tasks.description: Write an article requiring creative structure choice, audience adaptation, and synthesis of complex material
tasks.input: Write a 1000-1200 word article for a general audience explaining why quantum computing will not replace classical computers for most tasks, but will transform specific domains like drug discovery, cryptography, and optimization. The article must be engaging for non-technical readers while being technically accurate. Use a problem-solution structure: frame the common misconception first, then systematically dismantle it while explaining what quantum computing actually excels at.

scoring.5: Effective problem-solution structure: clearly frames the 'quantum will replace classical' misconception as the problem; systematically addresses it through 3+ domain-specific sections; each section debunks while reframing; conclusion synthesizes
scoring.3: Some problem-solution elements but the misconception isn't clearly framed upfront; structure drifts into general explainer
scoring.1: No clear problem-solution structure; standard expository article

scoring.5: Technically accurate explanation of quantum computing limitations and strengths; complex concepts made accessible through analogies and everyday language; no unexplained jargon; reader finishes with correct understanding
scoring.3: Mostly accurate but some oversimplifications are misleading; 1-2 jargon terms without explanation
scoring.1: Technical inaccuracies or overly simplified to the point of being wrong; heavy jargon
scoring.0: Technically incorrect or incomprehensible to target audience

scoring.5: All three requested domains (drug discovery, cryptography, optimization) covered with specific examples of quantum advantage; explains why classical computers struggle in each domain
scoring.3: Two domains covered well; third is superficial or missing
scoring.1: Only one domain addressed; others mentioned in passing

scoring.5: Compelling hook; sustained reader interest through varied techniques (analogies, questions, concrete scenarios); sentences are varied in length and rhythm; paragraphs are scannable
scoring.3: Reasonably engaging but flat in places; limited use of engagement techniques
scoring.1: Dry, textbook-like prose; no engagement techniques
scoring.0: Boring or confusing; reader would stop early

scoring.5: Conclusion synthesizes the domain examples into a coherent view of quantum computing's actual role; provides a forward-looking perspective that is both realistic and exciting; reinforces the thesis
scoring.3: Summary restates main points but doesn't synthesize into a new insight
scoring.1: Weak or missing conclusion

tasks.description: Write an article requiring integration of dependent skills (summarizer + keyword-extractor) with complex argumentation
tasks.input:
Here is a collection of raw research notes on microservices architecture:

- Netflix migrated to microservices in 2009-2012, reducing deployment time from weeks to minutes. Source: Netflix Tech Blog, 2016.
- A 2023 InfoQ survey found 78% of organizations using microservices reported increased deployment frequency, but 65% reported increased operational complexity.
- Martin Fowler warns about the 'microservices premium': the overhead is only justified at a certain scale. Source: martinfowler.com, 2015.
- Amazon's two-pizza team rule emerged from their service-oriented architecture. Each team owns one service. Source: 'Working Backwards', 2021.
- A 2024 DORA report found that elite performers using microservices deployed 973x more frequently than low performers, but the gap disappeared when controlling for team practices.
- Kelsey Hightower tweeted: 'Monoliths are the future because the people who are currently building microservices will realize that most of their problems don't require microservices.'
- Segment (analytics company) moved FROM microservices BACK to a monolith in 2018, citing excessive operational overhead for their team size. Source: Segment Engineering Blog.

Using this research material, write a 900-1100 word article for a CTO audience arguing whether startups should begin with a monolith or microservices. Summarize the research into coherent evidence, extract the key themes, take a clear position, and address counterarguments.

scoring.5: All 7 research notes are synthesized into coherent themes (not listed one by one); evidence is grouped by argument rather than by source; contradictions are acknowledged and resolved; demonstrates summarization capability
scoring.3: Most research notes used but presented sequentially rather than synthesized; some grouping by theme
scoring.1: Research notes copy-pasted or minimally rephrased; no synthesis

scoring.5: Core themes clearly extracted (deployment frequency, operational complexity, team size, organizational maturity); keyword coverage is comprehensive; themes drive the article structure
scoring.3: Some themes identified but article structure doesn't follow them; coverage gaps
scoring.1: No thematic organization; random coverage of research points

scoring.5: Clear position stated early; Toulmin model visible (claim, data, warrant, qualifier, rebuttal); evidence from research notes used as data with analysis; counterarguments addressed with specific evidence from the notes
scoring.3: Position taken but argumentation is shallow; evidence cited but not analyzed
scoring.1: Weak or shifting position; evidence not connected to claims

scoring.5: Every research note properly attributed (source, date); statistics include context; expert perspectives include credentials/relevance; case studies include outcomes
scoring.3: Most sources attributed but some are vague ('a study found...')
scoring.1: Poor attribution; claims presented as facts without sourcing

scoring.5: Framed in terms of business decisions CTOs face (team size, deployment speed, operational cost); actionable recommendation with specific conditions; professional, strategic tone; addresses real tradeoffs
scoring.3: Generally professional but doesn't specifically address CTO decision-making context
scoring.1: Too technical (developer-focused) or too high-level (executive summary without depth)
